item.title: Conclusion
item.description:
#hermes #hermes/conclusion

This section summarizes HERMES’s contributions and impact on edge security.


Summary:
HERMES: Hybrid AI/ML on ARM clusters.
98.3% detection rate, ≤47ms latency [26].
Privacy-preserving with Swarm Learning HERMES_System_Design_Architecture > Swarm Learning.
Impact: Open-source (MIT License), scalable for IoT/5G.
Future: Research in cryptography, 5G MEC [28].


Results: Summarizes Results.
Discussion: Builds on Discussion.
Blueprint: See HERMES_Blueprint_Outline > Conclusion.

[26] IEEE S&P ’24, “Conformal prediction,”
[28] IEEE Xplore, “5G MEC,”

#hermes #hermes/conclusion

item.title: Discussion
item.description:
#hermes #hermes/discussion #hermes/future_work

This section analyzes HERMES’s results, discusses strengths, limitations, and future work.
HERMES_Implementation_Details_Canvas
HERMES_Evaluation_Canvas


Strengths:
High detection rate (98.3%), low latency (≤47ms) [26].
Energy-efficient ARM cluster (see HERMES_System_Design_Architecture > Hardware).
Limitations:
Post-quantum cryptography overhead (~15% latency increase) [27].
MPC complexity for ultra-low latency [18].
Future Work:
Optimize cryptography overhead.
Integrate 5G MEC [28].
Implications: Scalable security for IoT/5G.


Results: Based on Results.
Architecture: Relates to HERMES_System_Design_Architecture.
Blueprint: See HERMES_Blueprint_Outline > Discussion.

[18] IEEE S&P ’23, “Homomorphic encryption,”
[26] IEEE S&P ’24, “Conformal prediction,”
[28] IEEE Xplore, “5G MEC,”

#hermes #hermes/discussion #hermes/future_work

item.title: Evaluation
item.description:
#hermes #hermes/evaluation #hermes/security

This section outlines the evaluation of HERMES, covering methodology and results for edge security performance.


Subsections:
Methodology: Datasets, metrics, setup.
Results: Detection rate, latency, energy use.
Purpose: Validate HERMES’s efficiency and accuracy against baselines like Snort/Suricata.
Datasets: Edge-IIoTset, 5G-MARS [24], [25].
Metrics: Detection rate (98.3%), F1 score (0.97), latency (≤47ms) [26].


Blueprint: Part of HERMES_Blueprint_Outline > Evaluation.
Methodology: Detailed in HERMES_Methodology.
Results: See Results.
Architecture: Evaluates HERMES_System_Design_Architecture.
HERMES_AI_ML_Components_Canvas

[24] IEEE Access 2022, “Edge-IIoTset dataset,”
[25] ACM WiSec ’24, “5G-MARS dataset,”
[26] IEEE S&P ’24, “Conformal prediction,”

#hermes #hermes/evaluation #hermes/security

item.title: HERMES Blueprint Outline
item.description:
#hermes #hermes/research_paper #hermes/blueprint

This document outlines the structure of a research paper on HERMES, a hybrid edge-resident machine learning system for network security on ARM clusters. It serves as the foundation for organizing the paper’s components.


Introduction: Introduces edge security challenges, HERMES’s solution, and contributions.
Related Work: Reviews existing IDS/IPS, AI security, and ARM cluster research.
System Design and Architecture: Details hardware, software, and AI/ML components.
Implementation Details: Describes technical implementation (e.g., eBPF, TF-Lite).
Evaluation:
Methodology: Datasets, metrics, setup.
Results: Performance metrics (e.g., 98.3% detection rate).
Discussion: Analyzes results, limitations, and future work.
Conclusions: Summarizes findings and impact.
References: Lists citations in IEEE format.

HERMES_Paper_Structure_Canvas


Format: IEEE conference style, two-column layout.
Length: 8–15 pages.
Visuals: Architecture diagrams, tables, performance graphs (see HERMES_Paper_Specifications).


Context: See HERMES_Context for background on edge security needs.
Specifications: Detailed in HERMES_Paper_Specifications.
Evaluation: Metrics and methods in HERMES_Evaluation, HERMES_Methodology, and Results.
Note Use this outline as a roadmap when drafting the paper. Ensure each section links back to this file for coherence.

#hermes #hermes/research_paper #hermes/blueprint

item.title: HERMES Context
item.description:
#hermes #hermes/security #hermes/iot #hermes/context

HERMES addresses the growing need for efficient network security in edge computing and IoT environments, where resource-constrained devices face sophisticated cyber threats.


Edge Computing Growth: Enables low-latency analytics but exposes devices to intrusions, DDoS, and data breaches [1].
IoT Vulnerabilities: Limited compute power and energy make traditional IDS/IPS impractical [2].
HERMES Solution:
Uses ARM clusters for cost-effective, energy-efficient security.
Integrates SNNs and GNNs for rapid threat detection (see HERMES_System_Design_Architecture > AI/ML Components).
Employs Swarm Learning for privacy-preserving updates (see HERMES_System_Design_Architecture > Swarm Learning).
Incorporates post-quantum cryptography for future-proofing (see HERMES_Implementation_Details > Security).
Evaluation: Achieves 98.3% detection rate on Edge-IIoTset and 5G-MARS datasets (see Results) [3].


Blueprint: Part of HERMES_Blueprint_Outline.
Introduction: Context informs HERMES_Introduction.
Evaluation: Results detailed in HERMES_Evaluation and Results.
Tip Link this context to specific threats (e.g., DDoS) in HERMES_Related_Work for deeper analysis.

[1] M. Satyanarayanan, “The emergence of edge computing,”
[2] IEEE Access 2022, “Edge-IIoTset dataset,”
[3] ACM WiSec ’24, “5G-MARS dataset,”

#hermes #hermes/security #hermes/iot #hermes/context

item.title: HERMES Introduction
item.description:
#hermes #hermes/research_paper #hermes/introduction

The introduction sets the stage for the HERMES research paper, outlining the edge security problem, HERMES’s solution, and its contributions.


Background: Edge computing and IoT enable low-latency analytics but face cyber threats (e.g., DDoS, intrusions) [1].
Problem: Traditional IDS/IPS are resource-intensive, unsuitable for edge devices [2].
HERMES:
Hybrid AI/ML system on ARM clusters.
Uses SNNs, GNNs, and Swarm Learning (see HERMES_System_Design_Architecture).
Achieves 98.3% detection rate, ≤47ms latency (see Results) [3].
Contributions:
Novel edge security architecture.
Privacy-preserving learning.
Evaluation on Edge-IIoTset/5G-MARS [4].
Structure: Links to HERMES_Related_Work, HERMES_System_Design_Architecture, etc.


Context: Builds on HERMES_Context.
Blueprint: Part of HERMES_Blueprint_Outline > Introduction.
Evaluation: Results in HERMES_Evaluation.

[1] M. Satyanarayanan, “The emergence of edge computing,” Computer, vol. 50, no. 1, pp. 30–39, Jan. 2017.
[2] S. Raza et al., “Intrusion detection in IoT,” IEEE Internet Things J., vol. 1, no. 4, pp. 316–323, Aug. 2013.
[3] IEEE S&P ’24, “Conformal prediction,”
[4] IEEE Access 2022, “Edge-IIoTset dataset,”

#hermes #hermes/research_paper #hermes/introduction

item.title: HERMES Paper Specifications
item.description:
#hermes #hermes/research_paper #hermes/specifications

This document specifies the formatting and content requirements for the HERMES research paper, ensuring compliance with IEEE conference standards.


Formatting:
IEEE style: Two-column layout, 10pt Times New Roman.
Sections: Abstract, Index Terms, I–VII, References.
Length: 8–15 pages, including visuals and references.
Visuals:
Architecture Diagram: Flowchart of HERMES pipeline (see HERMES_System_Design_Architecture > Figure 1).
Tables: Hardware/software specs, evaluation metrics (see HERMES_System_Design_Architecture > Table I, Results > Table III).
Graph: Performance comparison (see Results > Figure 3).
Citations: 25–30 IEEE-formatted references, focusing on 2023–2025 sources (see References).
Output: Ready for Word document using IEEE template.


Blueprint: Specified in HERMES_Blueprint_Outline.
System Design: Visuals detailed in HERMES_System_Design_Architecture.
Evaluation: Metrics in HERMES_Evaluation and Results.
Todo Download IEEE template and verify two-column formatting before submission.

#hermes #hermes/research_paper #hermes/specifications

item.title: HERMES Project Index
item.description:
HERMES_Blueprint_Outline - Outline of the HERMES paper structure.
HERMES_Context - Context and background for the project.
HERMES_Paper_Specifications - IEEE paper specifications.
HERMES_Introduction - Introduction section of the paper.
HERMES_Related_Work - Related work and literature review.
HERMES_System_Design_Architecture - System design and architecture details.
HERMES_Implementation_Details - Technical implementation details.
HERMES_Evaluation - Evaluation overview.
HERMES_Methodology - Methodology for evaluation.
Results - Results of the evaluation.
Discussion - Discussion of findings.
Conclusions - Conclusions of the paper.
References - References cited in the paper.


HERMES_System_Overview_Canvas.canvas - High-level system overview.
HERMES_AI_ML_Components_Canvas.canvas - AI/ML components breakdown.
HERMES_Evaluation_Canvas.canvas - Evaluation methodology and results.
HERMES_Implementation_Details_Canvas.canvas - Implementation details.
HERMES_Security_Features_Canvas.canvas - Security features of HERMES.
HERMES_Paper_Structure_Canvas.canvas - Overall paper structure.
HERMES_AllFiles_Canvas.canvas - Debugging canvas for link testing.

item.title: HERMES Related Work
item.description:
#hermes #hermes/research/literature_review #hermes/related_work

This section reviews prior work on IDS/IPS, AI-based security, and ARM clusters, positioning HERMES as a novel solution.


Traditional IDS/IPS: Snort/Suricata excel centrally but are resource-heavy for edge [5].
Lightweight IoT Security: Rule-based systems lack adaptability [6].
AI-Based Security: Random Forests, CNNs used, but computationally intensive [7].
Federated Learning: Enables distributed training, limited in security [8].
ARM Clusters: Energy-efficient, underexplored for security [9].
HERMES: Integrates SNNs, GNNs, and Swarm Learning (see HERMES_System_Design_Architecture) [10], [11], [12].


Context: Aligns with HERMES_Context > IoT Vulnerabilities.
System Design: Details in HERMES_System_Design_Architecture.
Blueprint: Part of HERMES_Blueprint_Outline > Related Work.

[5] S. Raza et al., “Intrusion detection in IoT,” IEEE Internet Things J., vol. 1, no. 4, pp. 316–323, Aug. 2013.
[6] M. Satyanarayanan et al., “Edge computing: Vision and challenges,” IEEE Internet Things J., vol. 3, no. 5, pp. 637–646, Oct. 2015.
[7] J. Anderson et al., “Machine learning for network security,” IEEE Trans. Inf. Forensics Secur., vol. 13, no. 6, pp. 1356–1368, Jun. 2018.
[8] B. McMahan et al., “Federated learning,” in Proc. AISTATS, 2017.
[9] ISCA ’24, “Heterogeneous edge acceleration,” in Proc. ISCA, 2024.
[10] M. Davies et al., “Advancing neuromorphic computing,” Nature, vol. 561, no. 7723, pp. 45–50, Sep. 2018.
[11] Z. Zhou et al., “Graph neural networks: A review,” IEEE Trans. Pattern Anal. Mach. Intell., vol. 42, no. 4, pp. 777–Apr. 2020.
[12] Nature 2023, “Swarm learning,”

#hermes #hermes/research/literature_review #hermes/related_work

item.title: HERMES System Design and Architecture
item.description:
#hermes #hermes/systems #hermes/architecture #hermes/ai

This section details HERMES’s modular, zero-trust architecture for edge security, covering hardware, software, and AI/ML components.
HERMES_System_Overview_Canvas



Pipeline: Packet capture → feature extraction → inference → mitigation → feedback loop.
Figure 1: System Architecture
ARM Cluster (Zero-Trust Fabric)



Nodes: Raspberry Pi 5, HoneyComb LX2, Jetson AGX Orin [13].
Table I: Hardware Specifications



Components: Ubuntu 24.04, seL4, Kubernetes k3s, eBPF, Redis/DuckDB [14–18].
Table II: Software Stack



SNNs: Short flows, 0.1mJ/inference [19].
GNNs: Long flows, 41% better DDoS detection [20].
Swarm Learning: Decentralized updates [12].
Figure 2: AI Inference Flow

HERMES_AI_ML_Components_Canvas


Blueprint: See HERMES_Blueprint_Outline > System Design.
Implementation: Leads to HERMES_Implementation_Details.
Evaluation: Tested in HERMES_Evaluation.

[13] ISCA ’24, “Heterogeneous computing,” in Proc. ISCA, 2024.
[14] OSDI ’23, “seL4,”
[15] USENIX Security ’24, “TDX containers,”
[16] ASPLOS ’24, “XDP,”
[17] IETF RFC 9368, “QUIC v2,”
[18] IEEE S&P ’23, “Homomorphic encryption,”
[19] Nature Electronics 2024, “SNN efficiency,”
[20] SIGCOMM ’23, “Topology-GNNs,”
[12] Nature 2023, “Swarm learning,”

#hermes #hermes/systems #hermes/architecture #hermes/ai

item.title: Implementation Details
item.description:
#hermes #hermes/implementation #hermes/security

This section describes the technical implementation of HERMES, focusing on packet capture, feature extraction, AI inference, and security measures.
HERMES_Security_Features_Canvas
HERMES_Implementation_Details_Canvas


Packet Capture:
XDP/eBPF on Linux 6.8+: 14Mpps [16].
AF_XDP sockets for high-speed filtering.
Feature Extraction:
NEON SIMD and memristor PIM: 22% energy reduction [21].
Features: TLS/JA4H fingerprints, QUIC spin bits [6].
AI Inference:
TF-Lite Micro with block-sparse pruning [22].
Integrates HERMES_System_Design_Architecture > SNNs and GNNs.
Security: cdef void entropy_neon(float[:] data): cdef float sum = 0.0 for i in prange(data.shape[0], nogil=True): sum += data[i] * log(data[i]) return -sum
Post-Quantum Kyber in TLS 1.3, TPM 2.0 [23].


Architecture: Builds on HERMES_System_Design_Architecture.
Evaluation: Tested in HERMES_Evaluation.
Blueprint: See HERMES_Blueprint_Outline > Implementation Details.

[16] ASPLOS ’24, “XDP,”
[21] Nature Comm. 2023, “Memristor,”
[22] MLSys ’24, “Block-sparse pruning,”
[23] NIST FIPS 203, “Post-quantum cryptography,”

#hermes #hermes/implementation #hermes/security

item.title: Methodology
item.description:
#hermes #hermes/evaluation/methodology

This section describes the evaluation methodology for HERMES, including datasets, metrics, and experimental setup.
HERMES_Evaluation_Canvas


Datasets:
Edge-IIoTset: IoT-specific traffic [24].
5G-MARS: mmWave attack traces [25].
Metrics:
Detection rate, F1 score, latency, energy use, cost.
Setup:
Heterogeneous ARM cluster (see HERMES_System_Design_Architecture > Hardware).
Real-time traffic simulation with GNS3.
Baselines: Snort, Suricata for comparison.


Evaluation: Part of HERMES_Evaluation.
Results: Feeds into Results.
Blueprint: See HERMES_Blueprint_Outline > Methodology.

[24] IEEE Access 2022, “Edge-IIoTset dataset,”
[25] ACM WiSec ’24, “5G-MARS dataset,”

#hermes #hermes/evaluation/methodology
